description: From Middle English exoneraten (attested in past participle exonerated), from Latin exonerāt-, the participle stem of exonerāre, from exonerō (“to discharge, unload; to exonerate”), from ex- (prefix denoting privation) + onerō (“to burden, lade; to load”) (from onus (“burden, load”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₃énh₂os (“burden, load”), from *h₃enh₂- (“to charge, onerate”)). The English word is cognate with French exonérer.

entries.meaning: (archaic) Freed from an obligation; freed from accusation or blame; acquitted, exonerated.

verbs.description: exonerate (third-person singular simple present exonerates, present participle exonerating, simple past and past participle exonerated)

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic) To relieve (someone or something) of a load; to unburden (a load).
(obsolete, reflexive) Of a body of water: to discharge or empty (itself).
(transitive) To free (someone) from an obligation, responsibility or task.
(transitive) To free (someone) from accusation or blame.
examples: Synonyms: acquit, exculpate; see also Thesaurus:acquit
